Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Hybrid Material Carry-On Shields for Civilians
Award.AbstractNarration:
The need for portable personal protection worldwide has increased dramatically in recent years due to extreme events such as deadly school shootings, the Boston Marathon explosion, and terrorist attacks. All the aforementioned events highlight an urgent need: civilians especially students and travelers need affordable personal protection. Therefore, developing multi-functional portable shields for civilians is a very important task. However, current personal protection products are not feasible options for civilians, because they cost too much and therefore lack practicality.

The proposed I-Corps project will investigate the commercial potential and viability of new hybrid material systems that offer reasonable protection in a practical way ? low costs and multiple functions. This transformative research is expected to yield a simple yet novel engineering material design (baseline materials with embedded interfaces/adhesive layers) to reduce impact damage and material costs. The proposed portable shields would not only provide enough resistance against bullets, knives and fragments during explosion, but also could be folded as temporary helmets during earthquakes and other unexpected dangerous situations. The societal impact of the project is significant, because numerous families will benefit from our proposed products when parents use them as special laptop cases during travel, and children could bring them in backpacks to schools. If successful, the outcome of this project will have significant impact on personal safety worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The need for portable personal protection worldwide has increased dramatically in recent years due to extreme events such as deadly school shootings, the Boston Marathon explosion, and other terrorist attacks. All the aforementioned events highlight an urgent need: civilians especially students and travelers need affordable personal protection.  Indeed, civilians almost have no option to protect themselves. In every violence case, before police came, people were killed or injured. Therefore, developing multi-functional portable shields for civilians is a very important task, especially the current personal protection products are not feasible options for civilians.  For example, body armor is too expensive and not convenient to wear every day. Based on the above hypotheses, an I-Corps team including a faculty, a graduate student and a business mentor investigated the commercial potential and viability of new hybrid material shields that offer reasonable protection in a practical way: low costs and multiple functions.

The I-Corps team conducted more than 150 customer interviews in the US and six Western European countries including France, UK and Germany. However, the results were very surprised to the team: in May 2015, US civilians did not think personal protection was urgent. In June to July 2015, people in Europe thought that they were much safer than US civilians because of deadly shooting cases in almost every week in the US. Therefore, the team had to change to another direction: developing novel football helmets, which would be beneficial to a few football players.  From November 2015, large-scale terrorist   attacks in Paris, France (the PI conducted customer interviews in June 2015 in Paris) and San Bernardino,California occurred. These events demonstrated that the team’s original idea was absolutely right--personal protection is very important and urgent. Therefore, although the team still plans to collaborate with a football helmet company in 2016, the team’s major focus is to develop carry-on shields® which will save civilians’ lives or reduce their injuries during unpredicted violence, earthquakes and even hunting.  Attached images show the prototype of a carry-on shield and demonstration by a French graduate student at New Mexico State University. According to the above dramatic customer discovery process, this project highlights a key issue of NSF research--advanced research should not be constrained too much by non-technical experts, otherwise, creative ideas would be terminated early. Moreover, this project demonstrates a critical need: NSF should get more funding and freedom to work better for civilians.
